questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a rash on his hands and feet for the past 2 weeks. The rash is intensely pruritic, especially at night. He has not had fever, headache, or diarrhea. His mother has a history of eczema. The child was due for an appointment later in the week to follow up on any potentially missing vaccinations. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Examination shows a maculopapular rash with linear tracks affecting the interdigital spaces of the fingers and toes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most effective intervention for this patient's rash?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is an antiviral medication commonly used for herpes simplex and herpes zoster infections, e.g., chickenpox. The characteristic chickenpox rash has various stages at once (including vesicles), begins on the face and trunk, and spares the palms and soles, none of which is seen here. This patient has scabies, for which acyclovir is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Supportive therapy alone (e.g., an antipruritic agent) is most commonly used for self-limiting illnesses like viral exanthem. This child has scabies, which does not resolve spontaneously. While supportive therapy may be used as an adjunct treatment, it will not address the source of infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Diphenhydramine is used for itching, allergies, and nausea. While this drug may be used as an adjunct to alleviate this child's symptoms, it will not treat the underlying Sarcoptes scabiei infection. Additionally, diphenhydramine should be avoided in children under 6 years of age.

D) CORRECT:

Topical permethrin is the first-line treatment for scabies and should be applied once on every part of the body and left on the skin for 8–12 hours before rinsing off; a second application may be necessary 1–2 weeks later. Alternative treatments include topical crotamiton, sulfur ointment, and oral ivermectin, although ivermectin is contraindicated in children < 6 years of age. Symptomatic treatment consists of oral antihistamines and, in severe cases, glucocorticoids. Since scabies is primarily transmitted via human-to-human contact, prophylactic treatment of all close contacts is indicated.

Because the Sarcoptes scabiei mite becomes more active in warm environments, the pruritus is intensified during the night or after a hot shower.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

E) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole is indicated for tinea, which typically manifests with an itchy ring-like rash with a red, raised scaly border and a central clearing. However, tinea does not occur simultaneously on all the webbed spaces of the digits and the itching has no relationship to the time of the day. This patient has scabies, for which topical clotrimazole is not indicated.
Image Description:

There is erythema and scaling between the second and third toes.

This is a typical finding in interdigital tinea pedis, which is usually associated with severe pruritus.
questions.hint: This patient presents with erythematous papules in the interdigital spaces associated with intense pruritus, especially at night. These findings are consistent with a scabies rash, which develops due to a hypersensitivity reaction to superficial burrowing (seen as linear tracks) of Sarcoptes scabiei.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man experiencing homelessness comes to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of a red, itchy rash on his hands. He says the itching is worse at night and often wakes him from sleep. Several other residents of the homeless shelter where he is staying have reported similar symptoms. Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. A topical drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most likely to be effective?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels is the mechanism of action of permethrin, the first-line therapy for scabies. The blockade of sodium channels results in delayed repolarization of neuron cell membranes, which causes paralysis and death of the mite. Topical lindane solution is an alternative for the treatment of scabies. It inhibits GABA release and causes neurotoxicity and mite death.

Oral ivermectin is another alternative treatment for scabies and is especially indicated in large outbreaks or severe forms of scabies.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) is the mechanism of action of corticosteroids. Topical corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone) are usually reserved for severe disease, especially when concomitant dermatitis is present. However, it would not kill the Sarcoptes scabiei mite.

C) INCORRECT:

Decrease in peptidoglycan synthesis is the mechanism of action of bacitracin and mupirocin. These agents are topical antibiotics that have no effect against the Sarcoptes scabiei mite.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of histamine-1 receptors is the mechanism of action of H1 antihistamines. Although an antihistamine would provide symptomatic relief for the itching and burning, it would not treat the disease, as it would not kill the Sarcoptes scabiei mite.

E) INCORRECT:

Increase keratinocyte turnover is the mechanism of action of topical retinoids, vitamin A derivatives. Topical retinoids are commonly used in the treatment of mild to moderate acne vulgaris. These agents have no effect against the Sarcoptes scabiei mite.

F) INCORRECT:

Binding of ergosterol, which creates pores on the cell membrane of fungi and disrupts the electrolyte balance, is the mechanism of action of amphotericin B and nystatin. These medications are not indicated for the treatment of scabies. Nystatin is used topically for oropharyngeal candidiasis (swish and swallow) and diaper dermatitis. Amphotericin B is used for severe systemic mycosis (e.g., aspergillosis). Neither drug is effective against Sarcoptes scabiei.
questions.hint: Pruritic, excoriated, erythematous papules with scattered vesicles on the interdigital folds and dorsum of the hand are a classic sign of scabies, which typically occurs in individuals living in crowded conditions (e.g., prisons, homeless shelters, nursing homes). Pruritis caused by scabies is often worse at night. Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei and transmitted by direct human-to-human contact.

questions.text:
An 85-year-old man who is recovering in a nursing facility following hip surgery complains of widespread itching, especially at night.
Examination reveals small papules, excoriated and somewhat hemorrhagic, over his fingers (figure), groin, and axillary regions.
In addition to washing all bedding, towels, and clothing in hot water and drying these items in a hot dryer, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Crotamiton is an alternative agent for treating scabies but appears to be less effective than permethrin.

B) INCORRECT:

Malathion is indicated for head lice but has not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for scabies, even though it has scabicide activity.

C) CORRECT:

Classic manifestations of scabies include generalized and intense itching that is worse at night. The lesions occur mostly in the finger webs, on the flexor surfaces of the wrists, on the elbows, in the axillae, and on the buttocks and genitalia; the face and head are usually spared.

The patient can be treated with topical permethrin 5% or, alternatively, oral ivermectin and be put in contact isolation. Healthcare workers or patients who have had direct, prolonged, skin-to-skin contact with the patient should also be treated, regardless of whether they have symptoms.

Key learning point: The first-line management for a patient with scabies is topical permethrin.

D) INCORRECT:

Lindane is third-line therapy after permethrin and oral ivermectin, but its use is limited by neurotoxicity. Lindane should be avoided in infants and pregnant women.

E) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod is an immunomodulator used to treat cutaneous warts, but it has also been shown to be useful in “field therapy” for actinic keratosis. It is neither effective nor practical to treat a patient with scabies with this medication because it cannot be applied to the entire body surface without causing significant irritation and systemic symptoms such as fever.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman with no significant medical history presents with new red, itchy papules on her palms, in her finger webs (figure), and on her abdomen.
Six weeks earlier, she had similar papules on her hands, umbilicus, and axillae and was diagnosed clinically with scabies infestation. At that time, her husband and 12-year-old son were asymptomatic; she was prescribed topical 5% permethrin cream, which was applied from the neck to the toes, left on for 10 hours, washed off, and reapplied one week later.
The rash improved dramatically after this treatment — until the new papules emerged several days ago.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Topical 5% permethrin cream for the patient only
Topical 5% permethrin cream for the patient and household members
Oral ivermectin for the patient only
Topical 1% lindane lotion for the patient and household members
Topical 1% lindane lotion for the patient only

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient responded well to the recommended treatment for scabies infestation, she was likely reinfested through her husband or son, neither of whom was treated initially. Because scabies infestation can be asymptomatic for 6 or more weeks after initial infestation, it would be incorrect to treat only the patient; all household members and close contacts would need to be treated to prevent reinfestation.

B) CORRECT:

Scabies is a common infestation that is characterized by extremely itchy, scaling papules and burrows that may occur anywhere — but in adults are often exaggerated in the finger webs, on the wrists, and around the breasts, umbilicus, axillae, and genitals. Scabies typically spares the head in adults.

Although this patient responded well to the recommended treatment for scabies infestation, she was likely reinfested through her husband or son, neither of whom was treated initially. Because scabies infestation can be asymptomatic for 6 or more weeks after initial infestation, all household members and close contacts should receive the same treatment as the patient: 5% permethrin cream applied from the neck to the toes, left on for 8 to 12 hours, and washed off, with the whole cycle repeated one week later. Clothing and bedding may also carry the mite, so all potentially involved clothing and linens should be laundered and dried on high heat or bagged for a minimum of one week.

Key learning point: When a patient is diagnosed with scabies infestation, the most appropriate next step is to treat the patient and all close contacts with permethrin, applied from the neck to the toes and left on for 8 to 12 hours and then washed off. This treatment should be repeated one week later.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral and topical ivermectin are also effective for scabies. Oral ivermectin should be considered as an adjunctive treatment with permethrin in patients who have received appropriate treatment with topical agents without success, who have had a recurrence, who have a severe case (crusted scabies), or who cannot tolerate topical agents. This patient’s symptoms resolved with topical permethrin, which would therefore be the preferred agent to treat the reinfestation. Even if ivermectin was chosen instead, it would be incorrect to treat only the patient; all household members and close contacts would need to be treated and, typically, permethrin would be chosen due to its safety profile. In very rare cases, oral ivermectin has been associated with systemic adverse effects, including seizures.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical lindane is effective against scabies, but its association with neurotoxicity has made permethrin the preferred treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical lindane is effective against scabies, but its association with neurotoxicity has made permethrin the preferred treatment. Even if lindane was considered, it would be incorrect to treat only the patient; all household members and close contacts would need to be treated to prevent reinfestation.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 15-month-old boy is brought to the clinic with a rash. His mother notes that he has been increasingly uncomfortable during the past 3 weeks, particularly at night, and has been scratching himself “all over.” He has never had a similar rash.
The rash is apparent on the child's feet (figure), hands, wrists, neck, stomach, and buttocks.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin condition that manifests as acute, itchy vesicles or localized, well-marginated plaques following exposure to skin allergens. It does not manifest with papules and nodules as in the current case.

B) INCORRECT:

Eczema is an inflammatory, relapsing condition characterized by pruritic, dry, oozing or weeping patches (acute phase) and scaly, thickened plaques (chronic phase). In infants, these patches often arise diffusely on the body accompanied by underlying xerosis (dry skin). Eczema does not result in persistent excoriated papules and nodules as depicted in this case.

C) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of scabies is based on history and physical examination. The classic manifestation is an intense, generalized pruritic rash that is typically worse at night. In adults, the lesions are often located within finger webs, on the flexor surfaces of wrists and elbows, and on the axillae, breasts, waistline, genitalia, and buttocks. In infants, the lesions are often very widespread with particular intensity on the scalp, face, palms, and soles.

Although a burrow (a serpiginous gray line in the skin formed by the advancing mite) is the classic sign of scabies, it may not always be identified. Typical primary lesions other than burrows are flesh-colored to pink or purple papules and nodules. Pustules may also be observed, often on the palms and soles. Secondary manifestations of itch (excoriations), immune activation manifesting as eczematous patches, and bacterial superinfection (impetigo) may also be observed.

The diagnosis of scabies can be confirmed by identification of a mite, mite eggs, mite feces, or all three on microscopic examination of scrapings of papules or burrows.

There are several available topical treatments for scabies in infants and young children. The most commonly used is 5% permethrin cream applied to the entire body from the neck down; infants with scalp or facial involvement may need treatment from head to toe. The cream should be applied at diagnosis and again in one week. All family members must also be treated at the same time. Itching, because it is a hypersensitivity reaction, can persist for weeks following treatment (“post-scabetic itch”).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a persistent 3-week rash characterized by extremely pruritic erythematous excoriated papules and nodules on the feet, hands, wrists, abdomen, and buttocks in a 15-month-old child is scabies.

D) INCORRECT:

Bedbug bites tend to appear as pruritic, erythematous papules or wheals with a hemorrhagic central punctum, clustered on skin that is exposed while the individual is sleeping. The history in this case of a persistent, relentless rash for at least 3 weeks makes bedbugs less likely, as they arise at the time of the bite and resolve within a few days without treatment. If continued exposure were occurring, new bites would be expected to emerge over time.

E) INCORRECT:

Bullous impetigo is a bacterial infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus that manifests with fluctuant, pus-filled bullae. S. aureus may secondarily infect scabies, but the morphology and history presented in this case make bullous impetigo as the primary or secondary diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents with a new pruritic rash and no other symptoms. He has numerous red papules and crusts with excoriations on the extremities and trunk with accentuation at the wrists. There are 5-mm linear tracks between the digits on his right hand (figure). There is no purulence or other signs of infection.
What is the most appropriate medical therapy, if any, for this patient?

choices.text: No medical therapy; wash bed linens in hot water and observe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In addition to receiving active medical therapy, families affected by scabies should decontaminate fomites such as bedding, clothing, and towels by washing them in hot water or sealing them in a plastic bag for at least 72 hours.

B) CORRECT:

Scabies is a common parasitic infestation that causes intense pruritus and inflammatory papules and tiny vesicles, typically on the hands, wrists, elbows, axillae, breasts, waistline, and buttocks. The presence of a burrow — a serpiginous, grey, scaly line in the skin — is pathognomonic for scabies. Symptoms (itching, skin lesions) appear 3 to 6 weeks after initial infestation and are due to a hypersensitivity to the mites, eggs, and feces.

The preferred treatment for scabies is two applications (7 days apart) of 5% permethrin cream over the patient's entire body surface from the neck down and under the nails. The scalp and face may also need to be treated in infants, with care taken to avoid the eyes. Simultaneous treatment is recommended for all household members and any other individuals who have had skin-to-skin contact with the patient in the month before diagnosis.

In addition to receiving active medical therapy, families affected by scabies should decontaminate fomites such as bedding, clothing, and towels by washing them in hot water or sealing them in a plastic bag for at least 72 hours. They should also engage in comprehensive housecleaning of carpets, fabric, and upholstery.

Key learning point: The recommended first-line treatment for scabies is 5% permethrin cream plus decontamination of fomites.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone may help alleviate the pruritus associated with scabies but will not treat the underlying infestation.

D) INCORRECT:

One percent permethrin lotion is used to treat head lice, but 5% permethrin cream is the preferred treatment for scabies.

E) INCORRECT:

Off-label use of oral ivermectin can be considered for cases of refractory scabies, cases of crusted scabies in immunocompromised patients, and cases in which adherence to two head-to-toe applications of topical agents is logistically difficult. The safety of this medication has not been established in pediatric patients, and it should not be used in children who weigh less than 15 kg.

On examination, you observe small papules, some excoriated and slightly hemorrhagic, over his fingers (see figure), groin, and axillary regions. E) INCORRECT:

Malathion is effective in treating head lice and scabies, but it is no longer approved for use in Canada.

questions.text: A 24-year-old college student presents to the emergency department with intense pruritus of her hands that worsens at night. Her roommate has similar symptoms. An image of her right hand is shown. What is the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Topical permethrin cream is the first-line scabicidal agent for treating scabies in adults and children. A single application is usually curative, with the option to repeat the dose in one week if needed.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is an antifungal medication that targets fungal infections and is therefore ineffective against scabies mites. This medication would not address the underlying parasitic infestation caused by scabies.

C) INCORRECT:

Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic used to treat secondary bacterial infections of scabies lesions but is ineffective against the mites themselves. This medication would not address the underlying parasitic infestation.

D) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin is an oral antibiotic that may be used to treat secondary bacterial infections of scabies lesions but is ineffective against the mites themselves. This medication would not address the underlying parasitic infestation.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone cream is a topical corticosteroid that may provide symptomatic relief of pruritus but is ineffective against mites. This medication would not address the underlying parasitic infestation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of generalized skin changes and itching. He has a 10-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia last year. He lives in a long-term care facility. Several other residents at his facility have recently developed pruritic rashes. Current medications include metformin, insulin glargine, and rituximab infusions. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. He appears uncomfortable. Examination shows thick, hyperkeratotic, crusted plaques with fissures on his hands, feet, and scalp. The skin is dry and covered with white scales in some areas. There are scattered excoriations but no pustules or bullae. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Crusted scabies (Norwegian scabies) is a highly contagious form of scabies that manifests with thick crusts or scales on an erythematous base with irregular borders, often involving the scalp, hands, and feet. Pruritus is slightly pronounced or absent, and the skin may show scaling and excoriations. Unlike classic scabies, crusted scabies involves a massive mite burden and can manifest with minimal inflammation despite extensive infestation. Diagnosis is confirmed by identification of mites, eggs, or fecal pellets on skin scraping microscopy. Outbreaks in institutional settings are common as crusted scabies is highly contagious. Aggressive treatment with a scabicidal agent is indicated for affected individuals and their close contacts to prevent outbreaks. Appropriate isolation precautions should also be taken to prevent transmission.
Image Description:

Thick crusts, scaling, and fissures on are visible on both hands and the left arm of this patient with AIDS.

This is a severe case of crusted scabies, a highly contagious form of scabies that typically occurs in immunosuppressed or debilitated patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Eczema herpeticum typically manifests with grouped, painful, umbilicated vesicles, which may be accompanied by fever and lymphadenopathy. This patient has no vesicles or fever and presents with thick, hyperkeratotic, crusted plaques with fissures, making an alternative diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Although seborrheic dermatitis can manifest with plaques and pruritus, this patient's hyperkeratotic crusting, fissures, and transmission within a care facility make an alternative diagnosis more likely.
Image Description:

Well-defined erythematous plaques are visible on the scalp.

This appearance is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Although psoriasis vulgaris can manifest with hyperkeratosis and scaling, the plaques in psoriasis vulgaris are not typically crusted, and fissuring is uncommon. Additionally, institutional outbreaks are rare.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous, partially confluent plaques with silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor and flexor sides of the legs.

E) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid typically affects older patients and manifests with large, tense, pruritic vesicles and bullae on an erythematous base. This patient has no bullae and presents with hyperkeratotic, crusted plaques and scales, making a different diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: This condition typically occurs in immunocompromised, debilitated, or older patients.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman from a nursing home is brought to the clinic for evaluation of a severely pruritic rash that has been present for 3 weeks. The itching is most intense at night and has been waking her from sleep. She notes that several other residents on her floor have developed a similar rash. Physical examination shows multiple erythematous papules and linear excoriations on her wrists and axillae. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen on this patient's skin examination?

choices.text: Annular lesions with central clearing on the trunk
Excoriated papules in the interdigital web spaces
Lichenified plaques in the antecubital fossae
Greasy, yellow scales on the scalp and nasolabial folds
Vesicles on an erythematous base in a dermatomal distribution

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Annular lesions with central clearing, or "ringworm," are characteristic of tinea corporis, a fungal infection. While tinea can be pruritic and contagious, the morphology of the rash does not match the erythematous papules and linear excoriations described. The typical locations for scabies (wrists, axillae) are also less common for tinea corporis.

B) CORRECT:

The intense pruritus in scabies, especially at night, is due to a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction to the mites, their eggs, and their feces. The pathognomonic lesion is the burrow, a thin, serpiginous track created by the female mite in the epidermis. These burrows are most commonly found in areas with thin skin, such as the interdigital web spaces, flexor surfaces of the wrists, axillae, areolae, and genitalia. The presence of excoriated papules in these locations is a highly characteristic finding. The contagious nature, evidenced by an outbreak in a nursing home, further supports this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichenified plaques in flexural areas such as the antecubital fossae are characteristic of atopic dermatitis (eczema). Although atopic dermatitis is pruritic, it is not contagious and would not cause an outbreak in a nursing home. Furthermore, the nocturnal intensity of the pruritus described is more specific for another diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

This finding is characteristic of seborrheic dermatitis. This condition typically affects seborrheic areas such as the scalp, face, and chest. It is not contagious and is usually associated with mild, not severe, pruritus. The location and clinical features do not align with this patient's presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

This describes the classic presentation of herpes zoster (shingles). Although common in older adults, shingles is characterized by a unilateral rash confined to a single dermatome. This patient's rash involves the wrists and axillae, which spans multiple dermatomes, and is not described as unilateral. Additionally, shingles is not contagious in a manner that would cause an outbreak of similar rashes.
questions.hint: Intense nocturnal pruritus, a contagious rash in an institutional setting, and involvement of the wrists and axillae are highly suggestive of Sarcoptes scabiei infestation.
